elements.content: The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity of the Fe/N/Carbon catalysts derived from the pyrolysis of zeolitic-imidazolate-framework-8 (ZIF-8) has been still lower than that of commercial Pt-based catalysts utilized in the proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) due to low density of accessible active sites. In this study, an efficient carbon-supporting strategy is developed to enhance the ORR efficiency of the ZIF-derived Fe/N/Carbon catalysts by increasing the accessible active site density. The enhancement lies in (i) improving the accessibility of active sites via converting dodecahedral particles to graphene-like layered materials and (ii) enhancing the density of FeNx active sites via suppressing the formation of nanoparticles as well as providing extra spaces to host active sites. The optimized and efficient Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.834 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode in acidic media and produces a peak power density of 0.66 W cm–2 in an air-fed PEMFC at 2 bar backpressure, outperforming most previously reported Pt-free ORR catalysts. Finally, the general applicability of the carbon-supporting strategy is confirmed using five different commercial carbon blacks. This work provides an effective route to derive Fe/N/Carbon catalysts exhibiting a higher power density in PEMFCs.

elements.content: Hydrogen-fed proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) hold great potential in mitigating environmental and energy crises. However, their commercialization on a large scale is primarily hampered by the presence of costly platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts for their oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) on the cathode side. In this regard, it is imperative to fabricate economical and earth-abundant PGM-free alternatives. Among them, transition metal and nitrogen-doped carbonaceous materials, for example, Fe/N/Carbon, are the most efficient materials. With a decade of effort, substantial advancement has been introduced in Fe/N/Carbon catalysts which still exhibit lesser activity than the commercially reported Pt/Carbon catalysts. At 8-fold higher catalyst loading (4 vs 0.5 mg cm–2 using 20 wt % Pt/Carbon catalysts at 0.1 mgPt cm–2 loadings), the activation polarization performance of the Fe/N/Carbon cathode can be comparable with that of the low-loading Pt/C cathode. However, the thick layer of the catalyst (100 μm in Fe/N/Carbon vs 10 μm in Pt/Carbon) results in severe mass-transfer problems and thus significant polarization loss at large current densities. To solve this issue, the Fe/N/Carbon catalytic activity should be further enhanced.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hydrogen-fed proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) hold great potential in mitigating environmental and energy crises. However, their commercialization on a large scale is primarily hampered by the presence of costly platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts for their oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) on the cathode side. In this regard, it is imperative to fabricate economical and earth-abundant PGM-free alternatives. Among them, transition metal and nitrogen-doped carbonaceous materials, for example, Fe/N/Carbon, are the most efficient materials. With a decade of effort, substantial advancement has been introduced in Fe/N/Carbon catalysts which still exhibit lesser activity than the commercially reported Pt/Carbon catalysts. At 8-fold higher catalyst loading (4 vs 0.5 mg cm-2 using 20 wt % Pt/Carbon catalysts at 0.1 mgPt cm-2 loadings), the activation polarization performance of the Fe/N/Carbon cathode can be comparable with that of the low-loading Pt/C cathode. However, the thick layer of the catalyst (100 μm in Fe/N/Carbon vs 10 μm in Pt/Carbon) results in severe mass-transfer problems and thus significant polarization loss at large current densities. To solve this issue, the Fe/N/Carbon catalytic activity should be further enhanced.

elements.content: The pyrolysis of the Fe-doped metal–organic framework (MOF), for example, ZIF-8, is one of the most promising processes to fabricate highly efficient Fe/N/Carbon catalysts, whose morphology and interior micropores can be largely retained after the pyrolysis. However, from the aspect of electrochemical reactions and fuel cell applications, such structures are unfavorable because reactants cannot reach the active site in the interior micropores of ZIF-derived particles due to deficient mass transport. In this context, the activity of ZIF-derived ORR catalysts could be further improved if their interior active sites can be exposed. Previously, various strategies were developed to expose the interior active sites of ZIF-derived particles. The most common strategy is to create mesopores or macropores in the ZIF-derived particles. For instance, the coating of SiO2 or the polymer layer on ZIF particles promotes the formation of concave structures with more exposed sites in the pyrolysis process; metal-assisted pyrolysis of ZIF particles produces hollow carbon spheres. Another strategy is to crack the dodecahedral structure of ZIF particles, converting them to a graphene-like layered structure with fully exposed active sites. However, in previous research, such a strategy has been only reported for the ORR activity in basic media in several cases and is still highly desirable, especially in the acidic medium.
elements.clean_text: The pyrolysis of the Fe-doped metal-organic framework (MOF), for example, ZIF-8, is one of the most promising processes to fabricate highly efficient Fe/N/Carbon catalysts, whose morphology and interior micropores can be largely retained after the pyrolysis. However, from the aspect of electrochemical reactions and fuel cell applications, such structures are unfavorable because reactants cannot reach the active site in the interior micropores of ZIF-derived particles due to deficient mass transport. In this context, the activity of ZIF-derived ORR catalysts could be further improved if their interior active sites can be exposed. Previously, various strategies were developed to expose the interior active sites of ZIF-derived particles. The most common strategy is to create mesopores or macropores in the ZIF-derived particles. For instance, the coating of SiO2 or the polymer layer on ZIF particles promotes the formation of concave structures with more exposed sites in the pyrolysis process; metal-assisted pyrolysis of ZIF particles produces hollow carbon spheres. Another strategy is to crack the dodecahedral structure of ZIF particles, converting them to a graphene-like layered structure with fully exposed active sites. However, in previous research, such a strategy has been only reported for the ORR activity in basic media in several cases and is still highly desirable, especially in the acidic medium.

elements.content: In the current work, we introduced an effective and facile carbon-supporting strategy to convert the dodecahedral particles to graphene-like layered structures to expose the interior active sites. This was realized by adding carbon black, for example, KJ600, in ZIF-8 synthesis. The KJ600 carbon black prevents the reassembling of cracked ZIF fragments and thus promotes the formation of dispersive graphene-like layered structures in the pyrolysis process. Additionally, the addition of porous KJ600 carbon black suppresses the formation of nanoparticles and provides extra spaces to host the active sites. Owing to the aforementioned advantages, the density of accessible active sites of the as-prepared catalytic materials (denoted as KJ-Fe/N/Carbon) increased to 4.8-fold of the reference sample, thus nearly 4-fold improvement of ORR mass activity was attained at 0.85 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The optimized KJ-Fe/N/Carbon cathode produced a peak power density (PPD) of 1.28 and 0.66 W cm–2 in oxygen and an air-fed PEMFC at 2 bar backpressure, respectively, outperforming most of previously reported PGM-free ORR catalysts. Finally, the general applicability of the carbon-supporting strategy was confirmed using five different commercial carbon blacks.

elements.content: The catalyst synthesis procedures are shown in a,b and are represented in detail in the Supporting Information. Briefly, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was fabricated via precursor pyrolysis, which was obtained by the solvent synthesis method, that is, the pristine KJ600 carbon black was first mixed with Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O and 2-methylimidazole in methanol and then stirred for 12 h. After adding FeCl3 solution and stirring overnight, the powder precursor was collected by centrifugation (labeled as KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8). The precursor was then pyrolyzed in an ammonia–argon (NH3–Ar) mixture to obtain the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. The molar ratio of NH3 in the mixture is 10%. The reference sample was obtained by processing the same experimental procedure without adding KJ600 (denoted as Fe-ZIF-8 and Fe/N/Carbon, respectively).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The catalyst synthesis procedures are shown in a,b and are represented in detail in the Supporting Information. Briefly, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was fabricated via precursor pyrolysis, which was obtained by the solvent synthesis method, that is, the pristine KJ600 carbon black was first mixed with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O and 2-methylimidazole in methanol and then stirred for 12 h. After adding FeCl3 solution and stirring overnight, the powder precursor was collected by centrifugation (labeled as KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8). The precursor was then pyrolyzed in an ammonia-argon (NH3-Ar) mixture to obtain the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. The molar ratio of NH3 in the mixture is 10%. The reference sample was obtained by processing the same experimental procedure without adding KJ600 (denoted as Fe-ZIF-8 and Fe/N/Carbon, respectively).

(c–h) TEM images showing the structural evolution from the KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 precursor to the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst: (c) precursor and after pyrolysis at (d) 700, (e) 800, (f) 900, (g) 950 , and (h) 1000 °C. (i–l) TEM images showing the structural evolution from Fe-ZIF-8 to the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst: (i) precursor and after pyrolysis at (j) 700, (k) 800, and (l) 950 °C.

(i-l) TEM images showing the structural evolution from Fe-ZIF-8 to the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst: (i) precursor and after pyrolysis at (j) 700, (k) 800, and (l) 950 °C.

elements.content: A transmission electron microscopy (TEM) investigation was carried out for examining the structural evolution of the catalysts. Before the pyrolysis, both KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 and Fe-ZIF-8 consisted of isometrical nanoparticles with a regular rhombic dodecahedral topology structure (c,i), representing efficient ZIF-8 particle synthesis. The formation of ZIF-8 is further investigated through X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Figure S1). Sphere-like KJ600 carbon blacks were clearly observed in the KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 precursor (c). When the KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 precursor was successfully pyrolyzed at 700 °C in the NH3–Ar mixture, the generation of cavities and pores in the interior of dodecahedral particles was observed (d). The changes are attributed to the decomposition of metal-imidazolate-metal linkages, which are driven by carbonization and NH3 corrosion. Such a phenomenon coincides with the Kirkendall effect. Upon increasing the pyrolysis temperature to 800 °C, the continuous decomposition and carbonization result in the crack of the ZIF particles, as shown in e. To minimize the surface free energy, the cracked fragments attached to the KJ600 carbon spheres (as indicated by the white box, e). At a higher pyrolysis temperature of 900 °C, graphene-like carbon sheets that evolved from cracked carbon fragments were uniformly dispersed on carbon supports (f). Upon further increasing the pyrolysis temperature, for example, 950 or 1000 °C, no observable alterations were detected in the morphology of the resulting products (g,h), suggesting that the optimal pyrolysis temperature is between 900 and 1000 °C. By contrast, in the absence of KJ600 carbon black, agglomerated particles were obtained (j–l), which may evolve from the reassembly of cracked ZIF-derived particles. Obviously, dispersive carbon sheets in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst can expose more catalytic sites than agglomerated particles in the neat Fe/N/Carbon catalyst.

elements.content: For determining the local chemical environment of Fe sites in the as-prepared catalysts, X-ray absorption spectroscopy, including X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) as well as extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS), was conducted. a represents the XANES spectra of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts with Fe foil and iron phthalocyanine (FePc) as references. The absorption edges of two catalysts located between the Fe foil and FePc reference suggest the average valency of Fe ranging from 0 to 2+. Compared to the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon sample manifests a closer absorption edge to the FePc reference, demonstrating a higher valence state than that of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. b compares the Fourier-transformed k 3-weighted EXAFS analysis of the two catalysts. The peaks located at 2.1 and 1.63 Å could be indexed to the Fe–Fe and Fe–N bonds, respectively. The main peak at 2.1 Å supports Fe species mainly in metallic nanoparticles formed in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. These nanoparticles are assigned to be γ-Fe according to selective electron diffraction analysis (Figure S2). By contrast, the intensity of the Fe–Fe bond at 2.1 Å decreases dramatically in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst, suggesting a significantly decreased content of Fe nanoparticles. c–f shows the wavelet transform (WT) of EXAFS of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts with Fe foil and FePc as references. WT-EXAFS plots can be used to distinguish the backscattering. The Fe–N and Fe–Fe bonds are located at different positions in the plots. The R-axis shows the bond length of the Fe–N and Fe–Fe bonds (c,d). In the k-axis, a higher value corresponds to a heavier coordination atom. The Fe–N and Fe–Fe bonds are located at 5.0 and 7.5 Å–1 in k 3-weight, respectively, resulting from the locations of the WT maxima which are highly predictable and correspond to the same location of the maximum in the q-space magnitude. As shown in e,f, a higher intensity of the brown color at 5.0 Å–1 suggests a higher portion of Fe–N x coordination in KJ-Fe/N/Carbon than in Fe/N/Carbon.

elements.content: The data obtained from EXAFS were then carefully fitted in the R-space (Figure S3). These fitting parameters are consolidated in Table S1. The Fe–N bond length in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst is nearly identical to that in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (1.99 vs 1.98 Å), suggesting a similar FeN x structure for the two catalysts, probably in the form of FeN4 sites. The same FeN4 active site for the two catalysts is further supported by the same Tafel slope in the acidic ORR, which will be discussed later. The average coordination number (CN) of the Fe–N bond in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst is 3.1, which is higher than 1.4 in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. The CN is a statistical result of Fe–N bonds, and the two catalysts are both composed of the single-atom FeN x sites and Fe nanoparticles. Therefore, if we assume that the two catalysts possess the same FeN4 structure, the higher CN implies the higher fraction of the FeN4 site among all Fe species. Thus, the higher CN in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst suggests a higher fraction of the FeN4 site among all Fe species than that in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. Similarly, the CN of the Fe–Fe bond in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst is 2.0, which is considerably lower than that in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (CN = 4.9). The lower CN in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst further supports a lower portion of Fe clusters among all Fe species. The XAFS analysis suggests that the addition of KJ-600 carbon black suppresses the formation of Fe nanoparticles during the pyrolysis process. One possible reason is the dispersion of Fe species. During the high-temperature pyrolysis process, the close-enough Fe atoms will agglomerate to form Fe particles. By adding KJ-600 or other carbons, these cracked ZIF fragments will attach to the KJ600 carbons to decrease the free surface energy, preventing the reassembly and increasing the physical distance of these fragments and therefore preventing the agglomeration of Fe single atoms to form Fe nanoclusters.

elements.content: Fe/N/Carbon and KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalysts were then analyzed via Ar adsorption/desorption isotherms. a shows that the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst exhibits a type-I profile, indicating a large number of micropores and relatively small external surfaces. In comparison, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows a typical type-IV isotherm along with a H3-type hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of mesopores. The decreased adsorption dose at a smaller relative pressure region (0 < P/P 0 < 0.05) displays the decreased micropore volume, while the quick increase of Ar adsorption at a greater relative pressure region (0.9 < P/P 0 < 1) implies the characteristics of macropores and large outer surfaces (multi-layer adsorption). The mesopore and macropore analyses are further confirmed by detailed Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore structure analysis between 2 and 100 nm (Figure S4). Quantitatively, compared with the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst, KJ-Fe/N/Carbon manifests a lower micropore (125 vs 435 m2 g–1, b) but a higher mesopore surface area (405 vs 216 m2 g–1). These obtained results are in good agreement with TEM observations. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy and XRD were conducted to analyze the defect of the carbon matrix and crystal structures (phase information) of as-synthesized catalysts. The two peaks located at ca. 1350 and 1590 cm–1 could be allocated to the D band (defects) and G band (graphitization), respectively. KJ-Fe/N/Carbon has a higher I D/I G ratio of 1.02 than Fe/N/Carbon of 0.76 (Figure S5). The 34% higher I D/I G ratio indicates more defects. Carbon defects are considered to be active to the ORR and benefit the formation of active sites, for example, FeN x . Figure S6 compares the XRD patterns of the two catalysts; both manifest two broad peaks at ca. 26 and 44°, associated with graphitic carbon. No prominent peaks associated with Fe nanoparticles are observed. This is because the lower quantity of Fe in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (1.71 wt %, measured by ICP-OES, Table S2) is insensitive to the XRD. The Fe content in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst increases to 2.82 wt %. However, most Fe species have a FeN x structure rather than nanoparticles, which are evidenced by HR-TEM images (Figure S7).

elements.content: For investigating the catalyst’s surface chemistry, an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) study was conducted. Figure S8 displays the XPS spectra of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The element contents of C, N, O, Fe, and Zn are calculated and presented in Table S3. The Fe quantity in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst is calculated as 4.82 wt % in the XPS survey, much higher than that calculated in the reference Fe/N/Carbon sample (2.63 wt %). XPS is a surface-sensitive characterization method with a detected depth of only several nanometers. The higher Fe quantity on the catalyst surface suggests a higher density of FeNx active sites. Nitrogen species on the surface can be deconvoluted into pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, and graphitic-N at 398.5, 400.2, and 401.2 eV, respectively (c). The deconvolution parameters are shown in Table S4. The surface element content is estimated to be 3.45, 1.34, and 2.26 wt % in the synthesized Fe/N/Carbon catalyst, respectively (d). The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows a 21% higher pyridinic-N content (4.18 wt %), 33% higher pyrrolic-N (1.78 wt %), and 24% lower graphitic-N content (1.71 wt %). In previous literature, researchers believed that pyridinic-N constitutes FeNx active sites. The greater pyridinic-N portion in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon sample further suggests more intensive active sites.
elements.clean_text: For investigating the catalyst's surface chemistry, an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) study was conducted. The Fe quantity in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst is calculated as 4.82 wt % in the XPS survey, much higher than that calculated in the reference Fe/N/Carbon sample (2.63 wt %). elements.content: One question that needs to be answered is why the Fe element content in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst is much higher than that in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (2.82 vs 1.71 wt %). In principle, the addition of KJ600 carbon black would dilute the content of the Fe element and consequently a lower Fe quantity in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon sample. To answer this question, Fe element contents in the Fe-ZIF-8 and KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 precursors are compared. It is found that the precursor KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 possesses a greater Fe amount than the Fe-ZIF-8 precursor (0.89 vs 0.63 wt %). The higher Fe content in the precursor KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 may be attributed to the absorption of Fe ions and 2-methylimidazole by the high porosity and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area of KJ600 carbon black (1371 m2 g–1). During the pyrolysis, these absorbed Fe and N species would transform to FeN x active sites or nanoparticles. Owing to the increased specific surface area of KJ600 carbon black, the formation of nanoparticles is largely suppressed, which is in agreement with previous studies. This is why we observe a higher Fe content in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst than in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst.

elements.content: Based on the above experimental explanations, the structural merits of adding KJ600 carbon black are summarized as follows: (i) converting dodecahedral particles into layered carbon sheets to expose interior active sites of the particles and (ii) preventing the formation of metal nanoparticles to enrich the number of FeN x active sites. (iii) Nanoporous KJ600 carbon black absorbs more Fe and N elements to form FeN x active sites in the following pyrolysis process, which provides a second routine to enrich the active sites as compared with the KJ600-free Fe/N/Carbon sample. The first merit improves the accessibility of catalytic active sites, while the rest two cause an enhancement in the active site density (ASD) of FeN x . These structural merits are expected to cause enhancement in accessible ASD and, therefore, improvement in the catalytic performance.

elements.content: To verify the increased performance of catalysts, the electrochemical properties of the resulting catalytic materials were estimated by rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) measurements in Ar- and O2-saturated (0.1 M H2SO4) electrolytes at 30 °C. As expected, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst fabricated at 950 °C shows the best ORR activity (Figure S9). a shows that the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst displays an E 1/2 of 0.834 V, higher than the Fe/N/Carbon (E 1/2 = 0.793 V), suggesting a greater ORR efficiency of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. b compares the ORR selectivity of two catalyst samples with the hydroperoxide (H2O2) yield and the number of electron transfer (n) as the indicators. Both the catalysts remain below 2% of the H2O2 yield in the potential range 0.2–0.9 V, and the relatively lower H2O2 yield and higher number of electron transfers of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon indicate a greater proportion of the 4e-ORR process. Figure S10 displays the Tafel slope of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The similar Tafel slope of ca. 60 mV/dec indicates the same reaction mechanism and active site moieties, consistent with the EXAFS analyses. The intrinsic ORR efficiency of Fe/N/Carbon catalysts is mainly examined through active site structure and density. Owing to the similar active site structure, the observed higher ORR efficiency of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst could be attributed to the higher ASD. To confirm the hypothesis, the ASD of catalysts was quantified by the previously reported nitrite stripping method, in which the integrated charge of nitrite reduction is utilized for calculating the number of accessible active sites. c,d shows the cyclic voltammetry curves of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts in the absence and presence of nitrite adsorption. The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst represents a higher integrated charge of nitrite reduction and thus has a higher ASD. Quantitatively, the ASD of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst reaches 58.5 μmol g–1 (e), which is 4.8-fold of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (12.3 μmol g–1). This result agrees well with the enhanced ORR mass activity of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon than with that of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (f, 5.02 vs 1.01 A g–1 at 0.85 vs RHE, calculated by the K–L equation).

elements.content: To evaluate the practical performance of the catalysts in the real-world energy devices, the H2–O2 and H2-air PEMFC tests were carried out. a plots the polarization and the power density curves (without iR-free) of the two catalysts in the H2–O2 PEMFC. The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst produces a PPD of 1.07 W cm–2 at 1 bar back pressure, which is equal to 1.5-fold of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (0.73 W cm–2). At 2 bar backpressure, the PPD of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst reaches 1.28 W cm–2, which ranks among the best PGM-free catalysts (Table S5). b displays the iR-free polarization curves of the H2–O2 PEMFC of both catalysts at 1 bar backpressure. The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst produces a current density of 0.032 and 0.044 A cm–2 @ 0.9 ViR‑free and 0.89 ViR‑free at 1 bar backpressure, respectively, surpassing most of the reported M/N/Carbon catalysts (Table S6). By contrast, the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst gives only 0.012 A cm–2 current density at 0.9 ViR‑free. In the more practical H2-air PEMFC, the PPD of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst reaches 0.59 and 0.66 W/cm2 at 1 and 2 bar backpressure, respectively (c). According to literature and our knowledge, this PPD is highest in H2-air fuel cells among all previously reported PGM-free ORR catalysts (Table S7 and d). The stability performance of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was investigated by the potentiostatic protocol operated at 0.6 V in the H2-air PEMFC. Figure S11 shows that the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst suffers from a significant catalytic decay (83% activity loss within the 40 h stability test). The decay mechanism and stability performance are rather complicated, which would be the focus of our ongoing study in the future.

elements.content: To verify the universality of the carbon-supporting strategy, Fe/N/Carbon catalysts, applying five different carbons, for example, KJ300, BP2000, XC72, MWCNT, and KJ600, were synthesized and evaluated in H2–O2 PEMFCs. a,b compares polarization curves and the power density curves of the five carbon-assisted Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The catalytic efficiency of the reference sample without carbon support is also shown for comparison. The carbon-supporting strategy boosts the fuel cell polarization performance of ZIF-based Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. To quantitatively compare the intrinsic ORR efficiency of the six Fe/N/Carbon catalysts, the iR-free polarization curves from 0.80 to 0.90 V are selected and presented in c. The current density measured at 0.8 ViR‑free can evaluate the intrinsic ORR efficiency of the prepared Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. A higher current density implies a superior intrinsic ORR activity. Without carbon support, the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows 0.15 A cm–2 current density at 0.8 ViR‑free. Assisted by the carbon-supporting approach, the current density measured at 0.8 ViR‑free increases to 0.22, 0.25, 0.26, 0.345, and 0.35 A cm–2 for BP2000, MWCNT, XC-72, KJ300, and KJ600, respectively. d summarizes the activity enhancement of Fe/N/Carbon catalysts for PPD and current density measured at 0.8 ViR‑free. It is found that the carbon-supporting strategy leads to at least 40 and 48% rise in the PPD and current density at 0.8 ViR‑free, respectively, demonstrating a broad universality of the facile strategy. Compared to the reference sample, these five carbon-assisted Fe/N/Carbon catalysts consisted of a similar layered structure (Figure S12) and higher Fe content on the catalyst surface (Figure S13), consequently leading to a higher density of ASD (Figure S14). This observation suggests the consistency of the mechanism for the activity enhancement.

elements.content: A universal carbon-supporting approach was conducted to enhance the ORR efficiency of the ZIF-derived Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The supported porous carbons promoted the conversion of dodecahedral particles into a layered structure, suppressed the formation of metallic particles, and provided extra space to host the active sites. These merits increased the accessible ASD and thus boosted the intrinsic ORR efficiency. The optimized carbon-assisted Fe/N/Carbon catalyst ranked among the best PGM-free catalysts in H2-air and H2–O2 PEMFCs. The current study offers an effective strategy to synthesize highly active non-PGM ORR catalysts, especially MOF-derived catalytic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A universal carbon-supporting approach was conducted to enhance the ORR efficiency of the ZIF-derived Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The supported porous carbons promoted the conversion of dodecahedral particles into a layered structure, suppressed the formation of metallic particles, and provided extra space to host the active sites. These merits increased the accessible ASD and thus boosted the intrinsic ORR efficiency. The optimized carbon-assisted Fe/N/Carbon catalyst ranked among the best PGM-free catalysts in H2-air and H2-O2 PEMFCs. The current study offers an effective strategy to synthesize highly active non-PGM ORR catalysts, especially MOF-derived catalytic materials.

elements.content: Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, FeCl3·6H2O, CH3OH, and C2H5OH were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). 2-Methylimidazole (2-mim) was obtained from Alfa Aesar. Ketjenblack EC600J (KJ600) was received from Akzo Nobel. Isopropanol and Nafion solution (Dupont, 5 wt %) were received from Sigma-Aldrich. 40% Pt/C (Johnson Matthey (JM)) electrode, gas diffusion layer (GDL Ballard 2240), and proton exchange membrane (NRE 211) were supplied by Xingqiao Energy Technology Co., Ltd. (Yangzhou, China). Highly pure O2 (99.998%) and Ar (99.999%) were obtained from Linde. All of the chemicals were of analytical grade and used as such without any processing. For solution preparation, deionized (DI) water (Millipore Milli-Q, 18.2 MΩ cm) was used.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, FeCl3⋅6H2O, CH3OH, and C2H5OH were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). 2-Methylimidazole (2-mim) was obtained from Alfa Aesar. Ketjenblack EC600J (KJ600) was received from Akzo Nobel. Isopropanol and Nafion solution (Dupont, 5 wt %) were received from Sigma-Aldrich. 40% Pt/C (Johnson Matthey (JM)) electrode, gas diffusion layer (GDL Ballard 2240), and proton exchange membrane (NRE 211) were supplied by Xingqiao Energy Technology Co., Ltd. (Yangzhou, China). Highly pure O2 (99.998%) and Ar (99.999%) were obtained from Linde. All of the chemicals were of analytical grade and used as such without any processing. For solution preparation, deionized (DI) water (Millipore Milli-Q, 18.2 MΩ cm) was used.

elements.content: KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 precursors were prepared using the solvent technique. In detail, 2.42 g of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, 2.95 g of 2-methylimidazole, and 0.1 g of KJ600 carbon black were uniformly mixed together by 12 h vigorous stirring in 100 mL of methanol. FeCl3·6H2O was completely dissolved in DI water to obtain a 1 M FeCl3 solution. Then, 0.16 mL of the resulting FeCl3 solution was transferred into the above-mentioned slurry and then stirred vigorously overnight at room temperature. The precipitant (labeled as KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8) was collected by centrifugation in methanol and vacuum-dried at a constant 60 °C for 12 h. The resulting KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 powder then underwent programming pyrolysis at 950 °C in an Ar/NH3 gaseous mixture (10% NH3, molar ratio) for 1 h. The ramp heating rate was 5 °C/min and cooled down to the room temperature naturally. Finally, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was prepared after the pyrolysis. For activity comparison, a neat Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (without deliberate adding KJ600) was also prepared (reference sample) following the same procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Catalysts

KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 precursors were prepared using the solvent technique. In detail, 2.42 g of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 2.95 g of 2-methylimidazole, and 0.1 g of KJ600 carbon black were uniformly mixed together by 12 h vigorous stirring in 100 mL of methanol. FeCl3⋅6H2O was completely dissolved in DI water to obtain a 1 M FeCl3 solution. Then, 0.16 mL of the resulting FeCl3 solution was transferred into the above-mentioned slurry and then stirred vigorously overnight at room temperature. The precipitant (labeled as KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8) was collected by centrifugation in methanol and vacuum-dried at a constant 60 °C for 12 h. The resulting KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 powder then underwent programming pyrolysis at 950 °C in an Ar/NH3 gaseous mixture (10% NH3, molar ratio) for 1 h. The ramp heating rate was 5 °C/min and cooled down to the room temperature naturally. Finally, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was prepared after the pyrolysis. For activity comparison, a neat Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (without deliberate adding KJ600) was also prepared (reference sample) following the same procedures.

elements.content: The catalyst ink for RRDE (working electrode: φ = 5.61 mm outer diameter of the glassy carbon (GC) disk having a Pt ring; Pine Research Instrumentation, USA) measurements was prepared according to the following recipe: 6 mg of the catalyst was dispersed into the mixture solution having 0.5 mL of water, 5 wt % Nafion solution (0.05 mL), and 0.5 mL of ethanol. After vigorous ultrasonication and agitation, 25 μL ink was then coated on the GC electrode with a catalyst loading of 0.6 mg cm–2.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the Working Electrode

The catalyst ink for RRDE (working electrode: φ = 5.61 mm outer diameter of the glassy carbon (GC) disk having a Pt ring; Pine Research Instrumentation, USA) measurements was prepared according to the following recipe: 6 mg of the catalyst was dispersed into the mixture solution having 0.5 mL of water, 5 wt % Nafion solution (0.05 mL), and 0.5 mL of ethanol. After vigorous ultrasonication and agitation, 25 μL ink was then coated on the GC electrode with a catalyst loading of 0.6 mg cm-2.

elements.content: The ORR polarization curves were carefully recorded in an O2-saturated (0.1 M H2SO4) solution on RRDE equipped with a CHI 760D electrochemical workstation. The GC plate and SCE (saturated calomel electrode) were used as counter and reference electrodes, respectively. All of the measured potentials were accurately calibrated to the RHE value using the Nernst equation: E RHE = E Hg/HgCl2 + 0.059pH + 0.2412. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) and ORR polarization curves were obtained at 30 °C and ambient pressure by potential cycling from 0.2 to 1.0 V (vs RHE) at a scan rate of 10 mV s–1. About 900 rpm was fixed as the rotating speed. Prior to the data collection, O2 or Ar was bubbled in the electrolyte solution for 15 min, and all of the catalysts are activated. For determining the H2O2 yield, the ring electrode potential was set at 1.30 V versus RHE for H2O2 oxidation that spread out from the disk electrode. The %H2O2 yield was measured from the disk current (I d) and ring current (I r) using the following equations H 2 O 2 % = 200 × ( I r / N ) / ( I d + I r / N ) n = 4 × I d / ( I d + I r / N )

Electrochemical Test

The ORR polarization curves were carefully recorded in an O2-saturated (0.1 M H2SO4) solution on RRDE equipped with a CHI 760D electrochemical workstation. The GC plate and SCE (saturated calomel electrode) were used as counter and reference electrodes, respectively. All of the measured potentials were accurately calibrated to the RHE value using the Nernst equation: E RHE = E Hg/HgCl2 + 0.059pH + 0.2412. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) and ORR polarization curves were obtained at 30 °C and ambient pressure by potential cycling from 0.2 to 1.0 V (vs RHE) at a scan rate of 10 mV s-1. About 900 rpm was fixed as the rotating speed. Prior to the data collection, O2 or Ar was bubbled in the electrolyte solution for 15 min, and all of the catalysts are activated. For determining the H2O2 yield, the ring electrode potential was set at 1.30 V versus RHE for H2O2 oxidation that spread out from the disk electrode. The %H2O2 yield was measured from the disk current (I d) and ring current (I r) using the following equations         H   2       O   2    % = 200 ×  (    I   r    / N )  /  (    I   d    +    I   r    / N )           n = 4 ×    I   d    /  (    I   d    +    I   r    / N )

The ORR mass activity at 0.85 V versus RHE was calculated by K–L calculations 1 / i = 1 / i k + 1 / i L

in which i represents the current at 0.85 V versus RHE, i k stands for the kinetic current, and i L is the limiting-diffusion current.

Measurement of ASD

The ASD was measured by a previously published nitrite reduction technique. The catalyst coated on the glassy electrode was first immersed in a 0.125 M NaNO2 solution for 5 min, during which NO2 – will be adsorbed on Fe–N x sites and then soaked in DI water for another 3 min to remove redundant NO2 –. After that, the treated catalyst was tested in Ar-saturated 3 M acetate buffer at pH 5.2 in the potential ranging from −0.3 to 0.4 V versus RHE. Under the potential ranging from −0.2 to 0.2 V versus RHE, the absorbed NO2 – will be removed entirely through electrochemical reduction. The fresh Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was employed again applying the same CV procedure to record the background curve. The integrated charge of nitrite reduction (Q) can be calculated by deducting the background CV curve. Correspondingly, the Fe–N x sites are equal in number to Q/5F. Electrochemical test conditions: Ar-saturated 3 M acetate buffer at pH 5.2; rotating speed = 900 rpm; scan rate = 10 mV s–1; loading of the catalyst = 0.27 mg cm–2; temperature of the water bath = 30 °C; potential range: −0.3 to 0.4 V (vs RHE).

elements.content: The composition and morphological analysis of the catalysts are performed through HR-TEM working at the voltage of 200 kV. XRD [Rigaku Ultima IV, equipped with the Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm)] at 35 kV and 15 mA current was carried out to characterize the crystal structure of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. Raman spectra were obtained using LabRam I (638 nm) to estimate the ordered and disordered degree of carbon skeleton of the catalysts. The BET surface area of the catalysts was estimated from Ar-adsorption isotherms at 87 K from the P/P 0 ranging from 0.05 to 0.35 (Tristar 2020). The data fitting is based on the slit pore model with Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size analysis for mesopores and macropores. The surface chemical properties were analyzed by XPS on a PHI Quantum 2000 spectrometer using monochromatic Al Kα radiation (225 W, 15 mA, 15 kV). The C 1s energy peak (binding energy = 284.5 eV) was utilized as a reference to calibrate the positions of other peaks. The Fe content was calculated through inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (Varian 700). The X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) at the Fe K-edge were obtained on the beamline BL11B (at Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility). The white X-ray was monochromatized using a Si(111) double-crystal monochromator, and employing a Fe foil (7112 eV), the energy was calibrated. The raw data obtained were carefully processed and then fitted applying the standard procedures with the Artemis and Athena programs. The EXAFS fitting was carefully processed in the R-space.

Physical Characterization

The composition and morphological analysis of the catalysts are performed through HR-TEM working at the voltage of 200 kV. XRD [Rigaku Ultima IV, equipped with the Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm)] at 35 kV and 15 mA current was carried out to characterize the crystal structure of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. Raman spectra were obtained using LabRam I (638 nm) to estimate the ordered and disordered degree of carbon skeleton of the catalysts. The BET surface area of the catalysts was estimated from Ar-adsorption isotherms at 87 K from the P/P 0 ranging from 0.05 to 0.35 (Tristar 2020). The data fitting is based on the slit pore model with Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size analysis for mesopores and macropores. The surface chemical properties were analyzed by XPS on a PHI Quantum 2000 spectrometer using monochromatic Al Kα radiation (225 W, 15 mA, 15 kV). The C 1s energy peak (binding energy = 284.5 eV) was utilized as a reference to calibrate the positions of other peaks. The Fe content was calculated through inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (Varian 700). The X-ray absorption spectra (XAS) at the Fe K-edge were obtained on the beamline BL11B (at Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility). The white X-ray was monochromatized using a Si(111) double-crystal monochromator, and employing a Fe foil (7112 eV), the energy was calibrated. The raw data obtained were carefully processed and then fitted applying the standard procedures with the Artemis and Athena programs. The EXAFS fitting was carefully processed in the R-space.

elements.content: The suspension of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts was carefully fabricated by completely dispersing 8 mg of the catalyst and 0.230 mL of 5 wt % Nafion into the solution containing DI water (0.2 mL) and isopropanol (0.8 mL) at a ratio of 1:4. After 1 h ultrasonic dispersion and agitation, the ink was dropped on a GDL (1.21 cm2, Ballard 2240) to form a cathode from the gas diffusion electrode (GDE), and the catalyst loadings for KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts were both kept at 3.2 mg/cm2. A commercial Pt/Carbon (0.4 mgPt cm–2, JM) GDE was utilized as both the anode and reference cathode in the fuel cell measurements. The membrane electrode assembly (MEA) was fabricated by sandwiching an NRE211 membrane between an anode and a cathode GDE through the hot-pressing method at ca. 5 MPa @ 130 °C which lasts for 2.5 min. Polarization curves as well as stability curves were recorded on the 850e PEMFC system (Scribner Associates Inc.) equipped with a potentiostat at a cell temperature of 80 °C. 100% humidified H2 [0.3 standard liter per minute (SLPM)], air (0.5 SLPM), and O2 (0.4 SLPM) with 1 bar or 2 bar inlet backpressure were fed as the oxidant and fuel at the cathode and anode, respectively.

Membrane Electrode Assembly Fabrication and Fuel Cell Tests

The suspension of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts was carefully fabricated by completely dispersing 8 mg of the catalyst and 0.230 mL of 5 wt % Nafion into the solution containing DI water (0.2 mL) and isopropanol (0.8 mL) at a ratio of 1:4. After 1 h ultrasonic dispersion and agitation, the ink was dropped on a GDL (1.21 cm2, Ballard 2240) to form a cathode from the gas diffusion electrode (GDE), and the catalyst loadings for KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts were both kept at 3.2 mg/cm2. A commercial Pt/Carbon (0.4 mgPt cm-2, JM) GDE was utilized as both the anode and reference cathode in the fuel cell measurements. The membrane electrode assembly (MEA) was fabricated by sandwiching an NRE211 membrane between an anode and a cathode GDE through the hot-pressing method at ca. 5 MPa @ 130 °C which lasts for 2.5 min. Polarization curves as well as stability curves were recorded on the 850e PEMFC system (Scribner Associates Inc.) equipped with a potentiostat at a cell temperature of 80 °C. 100% humidified H2 [0.3 standard liter per minute (SLPM)], air (0.5 SLPM), and O2 (0.4 SLPM) with 1 bar or 2 bar inlet backpressure were fed as the oxidant and fuel at the cathode and anode, respectively.

cln_elements.content: KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 precursors were prepared using the solvent technique. In detail, 2.42 g of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, 2.95 g of 2-methylimidazole, and 0.1 g of KJ600 carbon black were uniformly mixed together by 12 h vigorous stirring in 100 mL of methanol. FeCl3·6H2O was completely dissolved in DI water to obtain a 1 M FeCl3 solution. Then, 0.16 mL of the resulting FeCl3 solution was transferred into the above-mentioned slurry and then stirred vigorously overnight at room temperature. The precipitant (labeled as KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8) was collected by centrifugation in methanol and vacuum-dried at a constant 60 °C for 12 h. The resulting KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 powder then underwent programming pyrolysis at 950 °C in an Ar/NH3 gaseous mixture (10% NH3, molar ratio) for 1 h. The ramp heating rate was 5 °C/min and cooled down to the room temperature naturally. Finally, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was prepared after the pyrolysis. For activity comparison, a neat Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (without deliberate adding KJ600) was also prepared (reference sample) following the same procedures.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Catalysts

KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 precursors were prepared using the solvent technique. In detail, 2.42 g of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 2.95 g of 2-methylimidazole, and 0.1 g of KJ600 carbon black were uniformly mixed together by 12 h vigorous stirring in 100 mL of methanol. FeCl3⋅6H2O was completely dissolved in DI water to obtain a 1 M FeCl3 solution. Then, 0.16 mL of the resulting FeCl3 solution was transferred into the above-mentioned slurry and then stirred vigorously overnight at room temperature. The precipitant (labeled as KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8) was collected by centrifugation in methanol and vacuum-dried at a constant 60 °C for 12 h. The resulting KJ600-Fe-ZIF-8 powder then underwent programming pyrolysis at 950 °C in an Ar/NH3 gaseous mixture (10% NH3, molar ratio) for 1 h. The ramp heating rate was 5 °C/min and cooled down to the room temperature naturally. Finally, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was prepared after the pyrolysis. For activity comparison, a neat Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (without deliberate adding KJ600) was also prepared (reference sample) following the same procedures.

cln_elements.content:
The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activity of the Fe/N/Carbon catalysts derived from the pyrolysis of zeolitic-imidazolate-framework-8 (ZIF-8) has been still lower than that of commercial Pt-based catalysts utilized in the proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) due to low density of accessible active sites. In this study, an efficient carbon-supporting strategy is developed to enhance the ORR efficiency of the ZIF-derived Fe/N/Carbon catalysts by increasing the accessible active site density. The enhancement lies in (i) improving the accessibility of active sites via converting dodecahedral particles to graphene-like layered materials and (ii) enhancing the density of FeNx active sites via suppressing the formation of nanoparticles as well as providing extra spaces to host active sites. The optimized and efficient Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.834 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode in acidic media and produces a peak power density of 0.66 W cm–2 in an air-fed PEMFC at 2 bar backpressure, outperforming most previously reported Pt-free ORR catalysts. Finally, the general applicability of the carbon-supporting strategy is confirmed using five different commercial carbon blacks. This work provides an effective route to derive Fe/N/Carbon catalysts exhibiting a higher power density in PEMFCs.

In the current work, we introduced an effective and facile carbon-supporting strategy to convert the dodecahedral particles to graphene-like layered structures to expose the interior active sites. This was realized by adding carbon black, for example, KJ600, in ZIF-8 synthesis. The KJ600 carbon black prevents the reassembling of cracked ZIF fragments and thus promotes the formation of dispersive graphene-like layered structures in the pyrolysis process. Additionally, the addition of porous KJ600 carbon black suppresses the formation of nanoparticles and provides extra spaces to host the active sites. Owing to the aforementioned advantages, the density of accessible active sites of the as-prepared catalytic materials (denoted as KJ-Fe/N/Carbon) increased to 4.8-fold of the reference sample, thus nearly 4-fold improvement of ORR mass activity was attained at 0.85 V versus reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The optimized KJ-Fe/N/Carbon cathode produced a peak power density (PPD) of 1.28 and 0.66 W cm–2 in oxygen and an air-fed PEMFC at 2 bar backpressure, respectively, outperforming most of previously reported PGM-free ORR catalysts. Finally, the general applicability of the carbon-supporting strategy was confirmed using five different commercial carbon blacks.

Fe/N/Carbon and KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalysts were then analyzed via Ar adsorption/desorption isotherms. a shows that the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst exhibits a type-I profile, indicating a large number of micropores and relatively small external surfaces. In comparison, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows a typical type-IV isotherm along with a H3-type hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of mesopores. The decreased adsorption dose at a smaller relative pressure region (0 < P/P 0 < 0.05) displays the decreased micropore volume, while the quick increase of Ar adsorption at a greater relative pressure region (0.9 < P/P 0 < 1) implies the characteristics of macropores and large outer surfaces (multi-layer adsorption). The mesopore and macropore analyses are further confirmed by detailed Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore structure analysis between 2 and 100 nm (Figure S4). Quantitatively, compared with the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst, KJ-Fe/N/Carbon manifests a lower micropore (125 vs 435 m2 g–1, b) but a higher mesopore surface area (405 vs 216 m2 g–1). These obtained results are in good agreement with TEM observations. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy and XRD were conducted to analyze the defect of the carbon matrix and crystal structures (phase information) of as-synthesized catalysts. The two peaks located at ca. 1350 and 1590 cm–1 could be allocated to the D band (defects) and G band (graphitization), respectively. KJ-Fe/N/Carbon has a higher I D/I G ratio of 1.02 than Fe/N/Carbon of 0.76 (Figure S5). The 34% higher I D/I G ratio indicates more defects. Carbon defects are considered to be active to the ORR and benefit the formation of active sites, for example, FeN x . Figure S6 compares the XRD patterns of the two catalysts; both manifest two broad peaks at ca. 26 and 44°, associated with graphitic carbon. No prominent peaks associated with Fe nanoparticles are observed. This is because the lower quantity of Fe in the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (1.71 wt %, measured by ICP-OES, Table S2) is insensitive to the XRD. The Fe content in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst increases to 2.82 wt %. However, most Fe species have a FeN x structure rather than nanoparticles, which are evidenced by HR-TEM images (Figure S7).

For investigating the catalyst’s surface chemistry, an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) study was conducted. Figure S8 displays the XPS spectra of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The element contents of C, N, O, Fe, and Zn are calculated and presented in Table S3. The Fe quantity in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst is calculated as 4.82 wt % in the XPS survey, much higher than that calculated in the reference Fe/N/Carbon sample (2.63 wt %). XPS is a surface-sensitive characterization method with a detected depth of only several nanometers. The higher Fe quantity on the catalyst surface suggests a higher density of FeNx active sites. Nitrogen species on the surface can be deconvoluted into pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, and graphitic-N at 398.5, 400.2, and 401.2 eV, respectively (c). The deconvolution parameters are shown in Table S4. The surface element content is estimated to be 3.45, 1.34, and 2.26 wt % in the synthesized Fe/N/Carbon catalyst, respectively (d). The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows a 21% higher pyridinic-N content (4.18 wt %), 33% higher pyrrolic-N (1.78 wt %), and 24% lower graphitic-N content (1.71 wt %). In previous literature, researchers believed that pyridinic-N constitutes FeNx active sites. The greater pyridinic-N portion in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon sample further suggests more intensive active sites.

To verify the increased performance of catalysts, the electrochemical properties of the resulting catalytic materials were estimated by rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) measurements in Ar- and O2-saturated (0.1 M H2SO4) electrolytes at 30 °C. As expected, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst fabricated at 950 °C shows the best ORR activity (Figure S9). a shows that the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst displays an E 1/2 of 0.834 V, higher than the Fe/N/Carbon (E 1/2 = 0.793 V), suggesting a greater ORR efficiency of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. b compares the ORR selectivity of two catalyst samples with the hydroperoxide (H2O2) yield and the number of electron transfer (n) as the indicators. Both the catalysts remain below 2% of the H2O2 yield in the potential range 0.2–0.9 V, and the relatively lower H2O2 yield and higher number of electron transfers of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon indicate a greater proportion of the 4e-ORR process. Figure S10 displays the Tafel slope of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The similar Tafel slope of ca. 60 mV/dec indicates the same reaction mechanism and active site moieties, consistent with the EXAFS analyses. The intrinsic ORR efficiency of Fe/N/Carbon catalysts is mainly examined through active site structure and density. Owing to the similar active site structure, the observed higher ORR efficiency of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst could be attributed to the higher ASD. To confirm the hypothesis, the ASD of catalysts was quantified by the previously reported nitrite stripping method, in which the integrated charge of nitrite reduction is utilized for calculating the number of accessible active sites. c,d shows the cyclic voltammetry curves of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts in the absence and presence of nitrite adsorption. The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst represents a higher integrated charge of nitrite reduction and thus has a higher ASD. Quantitatively, the ASD of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst reaches 58.5 μmol g–1 (e), which is 4.8-fold of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (12.3 μmol g–1). This result agrees well with the enhanced ORR mass activity of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon than with that of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (f, 5.02 vs 1.01 A g–1 at 0.85 vs RHE, calculated by the K–L equation).

Nitrogen species on the surface can be deconvoluted into pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, and graphitic-N at 398.5, 400.2, and 401.2 eV, respectively (c). The deconvolution parameters are shown in Table S4. The surface element content is estimated to be 3.45, 1.34, and 2.26 wt % in the synthesized Fe/N/Carbon catalyst, respectively (d). The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows a 21% higher pyridinic-N content (4.18 wt %), 33% higher pyrrolic-N (1.78 wt %), and 24% lower graphitic-N content (1.71 wt %). In previous literature, researchers believed that pyridinic-N constitutes FeNx active sites. The greater pyridinic-N portion in the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon sample further suggests more intensive active sites.

To verify the increased performance of catalysts, the electrochemical properties of the resulting catalytic materials were estimated by rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) measurements in Ar- and O2-saturated (0.1 M H2SO4) electrolytes at 30 °C. As expected, the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst fabricated at 950 °C shows the best ORR activity (Figure S9). a shows that the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst displays an E 1/2 of 0.834 V, higher than the Fe/N/Carbon (E 1/2 = 0.793 V), suggesting a greater ORR efficiency of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst. b compares the ORR selectivity of two catalyst samples with the hydroperoxide (H2O2) yield and the number of electron transfer (n) as the indicators. Both the catalysts remain below 2% of the H2O2 yield in the potential range 0.2-0.9 V, and the relatively lower H2O2 yield and higher number of electron transfers of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon indicate a greater proportion of the 4e-ORR process. Figure S10 displays the Tafel slope of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The similar Tafel slope of ca. 60 mV/dec indicates the same reaction mechanism and active site moieties, consistent with the EXAFS analyses. The intrinsic ORR efficiency of Fe/N/Carbon catalysts is mainly examined through active site structure and density. Owing to the similar active site structure, the observed higher ORR efficiency of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst could be attributed to the higher ASD. To confirm the hypothesis, the ASD of catalysts was quantified by the previously reported nitrite stripping method, in which the integrated charge of nitrite reduction is utilized for calculating the number of accessible active sites. c,d shows the cyclic voltammetry curves of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon and Fe/N/Carbon catalysts in the absence and presence of nitrite adsorption. The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst represents a higher integrated charge of nitrite reduction and thus has a higher ASD. Quantitatively, the ASD of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst reaches 58.5 μmol g-1 (e), which is 4.8-fold of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (12.3 μmol g-1). This result agrees well with the enhanced ORR mass activity of KJ-Fe/N/Carbon than with that of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (f, 5.02 vs 1.01 A g-1 at 0.85 vs RHE, calculated by the K-L equation).

cln_elements.content:
To evaluate the practical performance of the catalysts in the real-world energy devices, the H2–O2 and H2-air PEMFC tests were carried out. a plots the polarization and the power density curves (without iR-free) of the two catalysts in the H2–O2 PEMFC. The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst produces a PPD of 1.07 W cm–2 at 1 bar back pressure, which is equal to 1.5-fold of the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst (0.73 W cm–2). At 2 bar backpressure, the PPD of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst reaches 1.28 W cm–2, which ranks among the best PGM-free catalysts (Table S5). b displays the iR-free polarization curves of the H2–O2 PEMFC of both catalysts at 1 bar backpressure. The KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst produces a current density of 0.032 and 0.044 A cm–2 @ 0.9 ViR‑free and 0.89 ViR‑free at 1 bar backpressure, respectively, surpassing most of the reported M/N/Carbon catalysts (Table S6). By contrast, the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst gives only 0.012 A cm–2 current density at 0.9 ViR‑free. In the more practical H2-air PEMFC, the PPD of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst reaches 0.59 and 0.66 W/cm2 at 1 and 2 bar backpressure, respectively (c). According to literature and our knowledge, this PPD is highest in H2-air fuel cells among all previously reported PGM-free ORR catalysts (Table S7 and d). The stability performance of the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst was investigated by the potentiostatic protocol operated at 0.6 V in the H2-air PEMFC. Figure S11 shows that the KJ-Fe/N/Carbon catalyst suffers from a significant catalytic decay (83% activity loss within the 40 h stability test). The decay mechanism and stability performance are rather complicated, which would be the focus of our ongoing study in the future.

To verify the universality of the carbon-supporting strategy, Fe/N/Carbon catalysts, applying five different carbons, for example, KJ300, BP2000, XC72, MWCNT, and KJ600, were synthesized and evaluated in H2–O2 PEMFCs. a,b compares polarization curves and the power density curves of the five carbon-assisted Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. The catalytic efficiency of the reference sample without carbon support is also shown for comparison. The carbon-supporting strategy boosts the fuel cell polarization performance of ZIF-based Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. To quantitatively compare the intrinsic ORR efficiency of the six Fe/N/Carbon catalysts, the iR-free polarization curves from 0.80 to 0.90 V are selected and presented in c. The current density measured at 0.8 ViR‑free can evaluate the intrinsic ORR efficiency of the prepared Fe/N/Carbon catalysts. A higher current density implies a superior intrinsic ORR activity. Without carbon support, the Fe/N/Carbon catalyst shows 0.15 A cm–2 current density at 0.8 ViR‑free. Assisted by the carbon-supporting approach, the current density measured at 0.8 ViR‑free increases to 0.22, 0.25, 0.26, 0.345, and 0.35 A cm–2 for BP2000, MWCNT, XC-72, KJ300, and KJ600, respectively. d summarizes the activity enhancement of Fe/N/Carbon catalysts for PPD and current density measured at 0.8 ViR‑free. It is found that the carbon-supporting strategy leads to at least 40 and 48% rise in the PPD and current density at 0.8 ViR‑free, respectively, demonstrating a broad universality of the facile strategy. Compared to the reference sample, these five carbon-assisted Fe/N/Carbon catalysts consisted of a similar layered structure (Figure S12) and higher Fe content on the catalyst surface (Figure S13), consequently leading to a higher density of ASD (Figure S14). This observation suggests the consistency of the mechanism for the activity enhancement.
